_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Alexander Chemical Corporation, a Carus Group Inc. company, is a leader in the water purification chemical industry. At Carus Group Inc. we manufacture quality products to help our customers solve environmental concerns and our vision reflects a long-term commitment to serve our customers. Carus supports the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care, an initiative that fosters involvement in the community and continuous improvement in environmental, health, security, and safety performance. Alexander Chemical Corporation is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and has been certified to be in compliance with the Responsible Distribution Code. The company is also an active member of the Chlorine Institute, a trade group that develops and establishes recommended practices for the safe handling of chlorine.

Carus Corporation's President and CEO states in their EHSS Charter that the Environmental, Health, Safety, and Security Mission is to achieve a manufacturing environment that we are proud of by continuously improving our ability to provide our customers with quality products and services that meet their needs while operating with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance. To operate with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance our commitment to EHSS must include: compliance with work instructions and procedures; clear expectations; a constant focus on prevention; active participation; awareness on and off the job; strong leadership; and personal responsibility. Further, a commitment to EHSS must include personal accountability for their EHSS performance and for the EHSS performance of those they manage or supervise. A commitment on the part of all employees and contractors is crucial to achieving the EHSS mission. Compliance with all expectations set forth in the EHSS Charter will help develop the EHSS culture and ensure Carus operates with the highest standards of safety and environmental awarenes

s. These expectations are a key part of job performance assessments. Carus will not tolerate failure to live up to the expectations outlined in this charter, as such failure could negatively impact the health and safety of our employees, our community, and the environment. The EHSS Charter has been reviewed and endorsed by Alexander Chemical Corporation, Mason plant personnel and plant management demonstrates EHSS leadership and commitment. In addition to EPA's RMP rule, the Mason facility complies with OSHA's Process Safety Management, EPA's Hazardous Waste Generator, DHS Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard and DOT's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration regulatory requirements.

The Alexander Chemical Corporation, Mason plant is a packager and distributor of industrial chemicals located in Mason, MI, which is located in a small industrial park in Ingham County. The Alexander Chemical, Mason plant has the following regulated toxic substances in excess of the threshold levels for 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (RMP): Chlorine; Sulfur Dioxide; Ammonia (anhydrous) and Ammonia (concentration 20% or greater). Chlorine, Sulfur Dioxide and Ammonia (anhydrous) are in quantities regulated by 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM). The Mason plant does not have any regulated flammable substances in excess of the threshold levels for 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (RMP)

The markets for the Mason plant include water treatment, wastewater treatment, industrial applications, agriculture, and food processing. Chlorine is distributed for the water treatment, wastewater treatment, and industrial markets. Sulfur dioxide is distributed for water treatment, wastewater treatment, agricultural and industrial markets. Anhydrous ammonia is distributed for agricultural, food processing and industrial markets. Ammonium hydroxide (aqua ammonia) is distributed for the wastewater t

reatment and industrial markets. To efficiently serve these markets, the Mason plant is operated as a storage and distribution facility for these regulated toxic substances. The processes involved for these regulated substances consists of movement and storage of these substances in their original containers. The process of movement includes unloading from the delivery truck, movement of these regulated substances in the warehouse and loading of the truck for delivery to their markets. The process of storage includes both internal warehousing of these regulated substances inside the building and external storage within a fenced and locked area. This secure storage area is located on the southwest side of the plant and inside the perimeter fence of the Mason plant. The PSM and RMP regulatory requirements are not applicable to the transportation of these regulated toxic substances.

There were four Worse Case toxic release scenarios and six Alternate Case toxic release scenarios assessed for the Mason plant. Section 2 of this RMP submittal contains additional details regarding each Worse Case release scenario while Section 3 contains additional details for each Alternate Case release scenario. 



The four Worse Case toxic release scenarios are briefly described and include: (1) structural fire involving a 9600# chlorine release of 64 cylinders (150#/ cylinder) with a distance to endpoint (urban) of 1.9 miles. Cylinders stored inside building; (2) structural fire involving a 6000# anhydrous sulfur dioxide release of 40 cylinders (150#/cylinder) with a distance to endpoint (urban)  of 1.6 miles.  Cylinders stored inside building; (3) structural fire involving a 9800# anhydrous ammonia release of 40 cylinders (140#/ cylinder) with a distance to endpoint (urban) of 0.9 miles. Cylinders stored inside building; and (4) structural fire involving a 19,744# release of ammonia liquid (concentration 20% or greater). Fire involves release of ammonia liquid contained in 8 totes (

2468#/tote) with a distance to endpoint (urban) of 0.1 miles. Release occurs inside building. 



The six Alternate Case toxic release scenarios are briefly described and include: (1) 150# chlorine cylinder release from sheared valve with a distance to end point (urban) of 0.1 miles. Cylinder stored inside building; (2) 150# sulfur dioxide cylinder release from sheared valve with a distance to end point (urban) of 0.1 miles. Cylinder stored inside building; (3) 140# anhydrous ammonia cylinder release from sheared valve with a distance to end point (urban) of 0.1 miles. Cylinder stored inside building; (4) Tote holding 2468# of ammonia liquid (concentration 20% or greater) punctured during movement with a distance to end point (urban) of 0.1 miles; (5) chlorine stored in 1 ton container located in outside fenced area within plant perimeter. Fire exposure causes fusible plugs to open resulting in release with distance to end point (urban) of 0.3 miles; and (6) sulfur dioxide stored in 1 ton container located in outside fenced area within plant perimeter. Fire exposure causes fusible plugs to open resulting in release with distance to end point (urban) of 0.2 miles. 

To ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint. The alternative release rate is a release that is considered more reasonable or "more likely." EPA's RMP CompTM was the release model used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint which becomes a radius for a circle around the covered process. Residential population within the circle is required to be determined based on available census information; hence, the population number for each scenario is reported as part of this EPA submittal. Since wind direction cannot be anticipated for an accidental release, EPA mandated the circle estimation method. This method greatly

over estimates the population potentially exposed to a release since the prominent wind direction and other factors are not taken into account. 



Generally, the Mason plant components for the accidental release prevention program includes a commitment to process safety, an understanding of hazards and risk, management of risk and learning from experience as well as compliance with regulatory requirements. Throughout the plant, a hierarchy of controls has been implemented (as applicable) including hazard elimination, substitution, engineering controls, administrative controls and personal protective equipment to minimize or eliminate exposure to hazards. The plant has a Process Safety Management (PSM) system for the covered processes as defined by OSHA. The Chlorine, Sulfur Dioxide, and Anhydrous Ammonia Processes include the following PSM system elements: process safety information; process hazard analysis; operating procedures; training; management of change; pre-startup safety review; compliance audits; incident investigations; employee participation; hot work permit; contractor management; emergency planning and response. Mechanical integrity program element is not applicable for this plant since it's a warehousing facility. The plant also has a safety management system for the Ammonium Hydroxide Process that includes the following elements: safety information; hazard review; operating procedures; training; maintenance; compliance audits; accident investigations; emergency planning and response. Infrastructure security improvements at designated areas in the plant have been implemented that provide layers of protection against deliberate man-made incidents in accordance with applicable elements of U.S. Department of Homeland Security's CFATS Risk Based Performance Standards.

Alexander Chemical Corporation has an extensive product safety stewardship outreach program for customers including four regional training sessions held recently that was attended by appro

ximately 450 personnel. These regional training sessions continue to be held periodically.

In the last five years, the Alexander Chemical Corporation, Mason plant has not had any accidental releases that meet the five-year accident history reporting criteria as required in 40 CFR Part 68.168. 

The Mason plant is actively involved in emergency planning activities as a member of the Ingham County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and has implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38. The Mason Plant EAP is derived from the Ingham County LEPC, SARA Title III, Fixed Site Response Plan which includes: means of reporting releases, fires and other emergencies to the Ingham County 911 Dispatch Center; evacuation procedures and emergency escape route assignments; reference to applicable procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate; procedures to account for all employees and other personnel on site after an emergency evacuation; rescue and medical duties for employees as appropriate; name(s)of Mason plant personnel or job title(s) who can be contacted for plant information or EAP duties, and information used by off-site responders to bring the emergency under control. The plan is reviewed annually by plant personnel, Mason Fire Department and other outside response agencies as appropriate. The plan is approved as a guideline for response to a hazardous materials incident requiring off-site response at the Mason plant and is consistent with the Ingham County and City of Lansing Emergency Operations Plans. The Mason EAP/Fixed Site Response Plan is exercised by plant management with the Mason Fire Chief determining date, time and type of exercise.

The PSM Program is reviewed and audited annually with areas for improvement documented and tracked to completion. Warehouse inventory controls have been improved to ensure that only adequate quantities of regulated toxic substances

are maintained to meet customer demands. Planned changes to improve safety include: the existing warehouse smoke/fire alarms will be monitored by remote security monitoring service (24/7); and, the parent company, Carus Corporation has created a position for a PSM Specialist to support plants in their PSM activities such as providing audit assistance, process hazard analysis lead/facilitator role, regulatory updates, PSM incident analysis and sharing best practices. Also, the PSM Specialist will provides leadership, culture, and policy guidance to Carus Corporation and Alexander Chemical Corporation management regarding Process Safety Management.
